articleContent.title: Chord: Major 7th in A# (Shape: D)
articleContent.content:
# Major 7th Chord in A# (D Shape)

## Brief Presentation
The major 7th chord in A# with the D shape is a lush and sophisticated chord voicing that brings a dreamy and introspective quality to music. This chord consists of the notes A# (root), D (major 3rd), F (perfect 5th), and G# (major 7th). When played in the D shape, it creates a unique and pleasant sound that can enhance harmonies in various musical contexts. 

## Notes and Intervals
- A# (Root)
- D (Major 3rd)
- F (Perfect 5th)
- G# (Major 7th)

Intervals: 
- Root to Major 3rd: 4 half steps
- Root to Perfect 5th: 7 half steps
- Root to Major 7th: 11 half steps

## Genre and Musical Flavor
The major 7th chord in A# with the D shape is commonly found in jazz, R&B, and neo-soul music. It adds a sense of sophistication, warmth, and smoothness to musical compositions. This chord is frequently used in ballads, love songs, and other genres where a touch of elegance and emotional depth is desired.

## Songs
Some songs that feature the major 7th chord in A# (D shape) include:
1. "Don't Know Why" by Norah Jones
2. "Cantaloupe Island" by Herbie Hancock
3. "Fallin'" by Alicia Keys
